factoid: The group meets tomorrow to murder one another.
The group kills and maims tens of thousands.
The group has thanksgiving services for having killed so many people.
The group exaggerates the number of people killed.
The group announces a victory.
The group supposes that the more people they have killed the greater their achievement.
Prince Andrew exclaimed, 'How does God above look at them and hear them?'
Prince Andrew says that it has of late become hard for him to live.
Prince Andrew says that he has begun to understand too much.
Prince Andrew says that it does not do for man to taste of the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
Prince Andrew says that it is not for long.
Prince Andrew says that the person is sleepy.
Prince Andrew says that it is time for him to sleep.
Prince Andrew tells the person to go back to Górki.
Pierre replies, 'Oh no!'.
Pierre looks at Prince Andrew with frightened, compassionate eyes.
Prince Andrew says, 'Go, go!'.
Prince Andrew says that before a battle one must have one's sleep out.
Prince Andrew came quickly up to Pierre.
Prince Andrew embraced Pierre.
Prince Andrew kissed Pierre.
Prince Andrew shouted, 'Good-by, be off!'.
Prince Andrew said, 'Whether we meet again or not...'.
Prince Andrew turned away hurriedly.
Prince Andrew entered the shed.
It was already dark.
Pierre could not make out whether the expression of Prince Andrew’s face was angry or tender.
Pierre stood in silence considering whether he should follow Prince Andrew or go away.
Pierre concluded that Prince Andrew does not want him to follow.
Pierre said, 'And I know that this is our last meeting!'.
Pierre sighed deeply.
Pierre rode back to Górki.
Prince Andrew re-entered the shed.
Prince Andrew lay down on a rug.
Prince Andrew could not sleep.
Prince Andrew closed his eyes.
One picture succeeded another in Prince Andrew’s imagination.
On one of them Prince Andrew dwelt long and joyfully.
Prince Andrew vividly recalled an evening in Petersburg.
Natásha had an animated and excited face.
Natásha told Prince Andrew how she had gone to look for mushrooms the previous summer.
Natásha had lost her way in the big forest.
Natásha incoherently described the depths of the forest.
Natásha described her feelings.
Natásha talked with a beekeeper she met.
Natásha constantly interrupted her story to say, 'No, I can’t! I’m not telling it right; no, you don’t understand.'
Prince Andrew encouraged Natásha by saying that he did understand.
Prince Andrew really had understood all Natásha wanted to say.
Natásha was not satisfied with her own words.
Natásha felt that her words did not convey the passionately poetic feeling she had experienced that day.
Natásha wished to convey that feeling.
Natásha said, 'He was such a delightful old man, and it was so dark in the forest... and he had such kind... No, I can’t describe it.'
Natásha was flushed and excited.
Prince Andrew smiled the same happy smile as then when he had looked into her eyes.
Prince Andrew thought, 'I understood her.'

Prince Andrew thought, 'I not only understood her, but it was just that inner, spiritual force, that sincerity, that frankness of soul—that very soul of hers which seemed to be fettered by her body—it was that soul I loved in her... loved so strongly and happily...'.
Prince Andrew remembered how his love had ended.
Prince Andrew said, 'He did not need anything of that kind.'
Prince Andrew said, 'He neither saw nor understood anything of the sort.'
Prince Andrew said, 'He only saw in her a pretty and fresh young girl, with whom he did not deign to unite his fate.'
Prince Andrew said, 'And I?... and he is still alive and gay!'.
Prince Andrew jumped up as if someone had burned him.
Prince Andrew began pacing up and down in front of the shed.
On August 25, the eve of the battle of Borodinó, M. de Beausset arrived at Napoleon’s quarters at Valúevo.
M. de Beausset is prefect of the French Emperor’s palace.
M. de Beausset arrived with Colonel Fabvier.
M. de Beausset is former from Paris.
Colonel Fabvier is former from Madrid.
M. de Beausset donned his court uniform.
M. de Beausset ordered a box he had brought for the Emperor to be carried before him.
M. de Beausset entered the first compartment of Napoleon’s tent.
M. de Beausset began opening the box.
M. de Beausset was conversing with Napoleon’s aides-de-camp.
Napoleon’s aides-de-camp surrounded M. de Beausset.
Fabvier did not enter the tent.
Fabvier remained at the entrance.
Fabvier talked to some generals of his acquaintance.
